awd_titl_txt: CIF: Medium: Foundations of Learning from Paired Comparisons and Direct Queries
awd_abstract_narration:
Direct queries and paired comparisons are popular means of data acquisition in various scientific disciplines. These two types of data have been studied separately, however, several modern applications -- particularly those involving human judgments -- require analysis of a combination of these two types of data. Such an analysis presents novel opportunities and challenges for stochastic modeling, experimental design and algorithm development. This research involves establishing a unified view of learning from direct measurements and paired comparisons with the aim of understanding fundamental limits and tradeoffs for various problems of interest, and developing and implementing practical algorithms that can leverage both types of data. The utility of the algorithms will be demonstrated by application to diverse domains including material science and crowdsourcing.

This project focuses on the specific technical problems of function estimation, feature selection, and optimization that can leverage passively and actively acquired direct queries and paired comparisons, with the following objectives. The first objective is to establish fundamental information-theoretic limits of learning from a combination of paired and direct measurements under various statistical models. These fundamental limits also involve understanding the inherent tradeoffs between the two forms of measurements that accounts for the different noise and costs. The second objective is to develop scalable and computationally efficient algorithms whose performance attains these fundamental limits. The third objective is to transfer the theory to practice in applications such as material design using direct experimental and pairwise expert feedback.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching objective of this project is to establish the fundamental limits and design algorithms for inference with a focus on multiple types of data, such as, pairwise comparisons and direct queries.


In delving into the landscape of data scenarios, the research extensively explored settings involving diverse types of data. Here are four examples of such settings: 

(i) When asking people to evaluate items, there has been a long-standing debate on whether to ask people to provide ratings for the items, or whether to ask them to rank the items. However, some applications may benefit from having both, and we study this setting which has received scant attention previously.

(ii) There are a variety of application domains in which evaluations themselves need to be evaluated for quality control. We consider pairs of (evaluation, evaluation of evaluation) settings.

(iii) The need for anonymity is widely debated in contexts such as scientific peer review, and we analyze data from anonymous sources juxtaposed with those from non-anonymous sources.

(iv) Many rating systems ask raters to not only provide an overall rating, but also ratings pertaining to individual criteria. For instance, travel websites ask travelers to provide an overall rating for any hotel in addition to rating individual criteria such as cleanliness, service, location, among others. We consider data encompassing both criteria and overall ratings. 


In each of these settings, our research has made contributions across various facets of these problems. First, our research has established fundamental limits on what can be done with these types of data. These results design and use tools from the field of information theory, and the results enumerate the realms of possibility in these settings. These foundational results also help shed light on classical questions from a foundational viewpoint, for instance, by establishing a fundamental comparison between data from rankings and ratings. 


The second class of contributions builds on the fundamental limits that we established. Using these results on fundamental limits as guidelines, we have developed a number of practical algorithms to process these multiple types of data simultaneously, and our algorithms are applicable to a variety of settings. In addition, we have also supplemented many of our algorithms with strong mathematical guarantees on their performance, thereby guaranteeing their robustness even in challenging scenarios. 


The third set of contributions then involves an implementation of our algorithms, and releasing them publicly for free. We evaluate our proposed algorithms in the aforementioned domains, and these evaluations reveal a strong performance of our algorithms.


The outcomes of this research have received several best paper awards. It has also made a real-world impact, having been deployed in several applications and exhibiting a strong performance therein. 


Finally, the research also involved considerable outreach with numerous talks and tutorials given by the PIs pertaining to the outcomes of this research.
